data.text:
Tumakuru formerly known as Tumkur is known as the city of education and interestingly, the city of coconuts. There are many folks as to how this city got its name, but many believe that it came from or was derived from “tumbe ooru.” This is because tumbe huuvu is a kind of flower found in abundance here.

Tumakuru is a great place to visit due to its scenic beauty and closeness to nature and many other reasons. So, if you are planning to visit Tumakuru, then here are a few places you can consider visiting.

1. Devarayanadurga State Forest:

Devarayanadurga is a hill station located in the state of Karnataka. The surrounding forests are a place for many temples. The forests in this area are uniquely dry and deciduous. Being 60 Kms from Bangalore it is a drive to remember and a place to cherish. Many tourists prefer getting there early to catch the beautiful sunrise. Due to its forests, Devarayanadurga State Forest is home to plenty of animals, wildlife ranging from wild boars, long billed and white backed vultures, leopards etc. live here. They have nearly 250 species of birds and more than 50 types of butterflies!

2. Chennakeshava Temple, Aralaguppe:

This temple is located in the small town of Aralaguppe was made as a dedication to the Hindu god Vishnu. This temple has been around for a long time. It was built in around 1250 A.D under the rule of the Hoysala Empire King Vira Someshwara. The fact that it lasted so long is a credit to its architects. To be precise, it is a living proof, of the architectural prowess of the Hoysala Empire. The temple is raised on a platform called jagati. The temple has two eaves. The first runs below the massive structure and all around it. The second eave goes around the temple by about a meter below the first. In between the two eaves are miniature towers. A visit to this temple is an architectural master class. It is an architectural wonder to witness.

3. Pavagada Fort

This 600 year old fort speaks to us of a rich history and beckons us to use our imagination while marveling at the way it’s made. The Pavagada fort is a reminder of the past and it teases its viewer to know more. Built by a Vijayanagar chieftain, the fort is a multi-level structure with several enclosures, massive watchtowers, and bunkers.

The entire complex is home to a mosque, a pond, and a huge bunker. This fort has seven levels of fortification to it. It was built during a time when wars between wars were prevalent and having a strong fort often meant life. It has a secret tunnel that was built for the king’s escape contributing to the fact, that this fort was war ready. As you trek up to the fort, you can’t help but wonder at this architectural marvel.

The fact that this fort is in such good condition is proof of the amazing architectural skills of the then engineers. It is said that this fort saw many battles and still stood strong. The way to the top of the fort is tedious but it has many places to rest, so be assured, it is possible.

As you visit this fort, you can’t help but be taken back to the time this fort must have been thriving. As you get here, feel its energy, relive the past, read up on its history.

Take a train to Tumkur

There are 86 trains from Bangalore to Tumkur on a weekly basis. Some of them are listed below for your consideration. You can search details on travel portal regarding the trains to book your ticket to Tumkur.

12079: Janshatabdi Express

12725: Intercity Express

16201: Bangalore Cy Junction Shimoga Town Express

16508: Jodhpur Express

16506: Gandhidham Express

The first train from Bangalore departs at 00:10 AM and the last train departs at 23:30 PM. You can book tickets in the train, which seems convenient to you as per your timing and schedule.
